qas.question: In 1887 the US Government wanted to undo Bell's patent due to fraud and what?
The US Government lost the bid to overturn Bell's patent in what court?
How many years did Bell and the US Government fight in court?
What excuse did the judges have for the trial despite the fact that the patents had expired?
On what date did the US Government stop legal action?

context: On January 13, 1887, the U,S. Government moved to annul the patent issued to Bell on the grounds of fraud and <a0_0>misrepresentation<a0_0/>. After a series of decisions and reversals, the Bell company won a decision in the <a1_0>Supreme Court<a1_0/>, though a couple of the original claims from the lower court cases were left undecided. By the time that the trial wound its way through nine years of legal battles, the U.S. prosecuting attorney had died and the two Bell patents (No. 174,465 dated March 7, 1876 and No. 186,787 dated January 30, 1877) were no longer in effect, although the presiding judges agreed to continue the proceedings due to the case's importance as a "<a3_0>precedent<a3_0/>". With a change in administration and charges of conflict of interest (on both sides) arising from the original trial, the US Attorney General dropped the lawsuit on <a4_0>November 30, 18<a2_0>9<a2_0/>7<a4_0/> leaving several issues undecided on the merits.
